**Industrial‑Sector Threat Intelligence Report – 30 day window (23 Dec 2025 – 2 Jan 2026)** *Prepared by: [Your Name], Senior Cyber‑Security Analyst – Industrials* --- ## 1. Executive Summary The past month has been unusually active for the **Industrials** ecosystem. Ransomware operators have continued to target high‑value manufacturing and energy assets (e.g., the **Oltenia Energy Complex** in Romania and the **Chrysler** automotive platform). At the same time, **state‑aligned APT groups** (Mustang Panda/Evasive Panda, Noname057) have expanded their tooling to include signed kernel‑mode rootkits and DNS‑poisoning chains that can be leveraged against OT/IT convergence points. A second, more subtle trend is the **proliferation of supply‑chain compromises** that affect industrial software stacks: malicious NPM packages (Shai‑Hulud), compromised download pages for the EmEditor editor, and the continued exploitation of the **MongoDB “MongoBleed” (CVE‑2025‑14847)** flaw, which is now listed in multiple national KEV catalogs and is actively scanned across industrial networks. **Critical security topics for Industrials** this period: | Topic | Why it matters to Industrials | |-------|------------------------------| | **Ransomware on critical infrastructure** (energy, automotive, aerospace) | Direct production downtime, safety‑critical system shutdown, regulatory penalties. | | **Supply‑chain attacks on development toolchains** (npm, EmEditor, IBM API Connect) | Compromise of build pipelines can inject malware into firmware, PLC code, or SCADA components. | | **Kernel‑mode rootkits & signed driver abuse** (Mustang Panda, HoneyMyte) | Ability to bypass secure boot and persist on OT gateways, PLCs, and edge gateways. | | **Active exploitation of MongoDB and other database services** (MongoBleed, CVE‑2025‑14847) | Many industrial control systems store telemetry in MongoDB; unauthenticated reads expose process data and credentials. | | **Utility‑specific data for sale** (US utility infrastructure files) | Threat of coordinated sabotage or extortion against power grids and water treatment plants. | | **OT/IT convergence security gaps** (Palo Alto OT/IT convergence brief) | Growing attack surface as legacy OT is exposed to corporate networks and cloud services. | Overall, the threat landscape is moving from “loud ransomware” toward **multi‑vector, supply‑chain‑first campaigns** that can silently embed malicious code into industrial products before they ever reach the plant floor. --- ## 2. Threat Actor Intelligence | Actor / Group | Targeted Industrial Sub‑Sector | Campaign Highlights (30‑day window) | Tactics, Techniques, Procedures (TTPs) | |---------------|-------------------------------|------------------------------------|----------------------------------------| | **Everest Ransomware** (ALPHV/BlackCat affiliate) | Automotive (Chrysler) & Electronics (ASUS) | • Stole >1 TB of Chrysler design & test data (HackRead, 26 Dec).
• Leaked 1 TB of ASUS data (HackRead, 31 Dec). | • Double‑extortion: exfiltration + ransomware.
• Use of **Cobalt Strike** and **CVE‑2024‑####** exploits for lateral movement.
• Targeted **ERP/PLM** systems (e.g., Siemens Teamcenter, SAP). | | **Noname057** (Pro‑Russian hacktivist) | Postal & logistics (La Poste) – not core industrial but impacts supply‑chain logistics. | • Claimed DDoS & credential theft on La Poste services (SecurityAffairs, 26 Dec). | • Credential dumping, credential‑reuse attacks on VPN/remote‑access. | | **Mustang Panda / HoneyMyte** (China‑linked APT) | Broad – OT gateways, industrial edge devices, manufacturing execution systems (MES). | • Deployed **ToneShell** via **signed kernel‑mode rootkit driver** (SecurityAffairs, 30 Dec).
• Similar activity reported by The Hacker News (08 Jan 2026). | • Abuse of **WHQL‑signed drivers** to bypass Secure Boot.
• Use of **kernel‑mode rootkits** for stealth persistence.
• Targeted DNS‑poisoning (Evasive Panda) to deliver **MgBot** malware (The Hacker News, 26 Dec). | | **RondoDox Botnet** (criminal botnet) | IoT/Industrial IoT (edge sensors, PLC gateways) | • Exploits **React2Shell** (critical RCE) to hijack IoT devices (The Hacker News, 15 Jan). | • Mass‑scanning of **React2Shell** vulnerable web‑apps.
• Deploys **cryptominers** and **remote access tools**. | | **Shai‑Hulud** (Supply‑chain NPM actor) | Software development pipelines used by industrial OEMs | • Compromised NPM packages used to inject malicious code into **Trust Wallet** (multiple reports).
• Modified version observed targeting npm registry (The Hacker News, 31 Dec). | • **Supply‑chain poisoning** of npm packages.
• Credential theft via **web‑hook** exfiltration. | | **Utility‑Info Seller** (unknown cyber‑criminal) | Power & water utilities (US) | • Advertised sale of internal schematics, network diagrams for three major US utilities (The Register, 02 Jan). | • Data‑as‑a‑service for extortion or sabotage planning. | | **Evasive Panda** (China‑linked) | General – DNS infrastructure used by industrial sites | • DNS‑poisoning campaign delivering **MgBot** (The Hacker News, 26 Dec). | • Manipulation of DNS resolvers to redirect OT traffic to malicious C2. | **Supply‑Chain Risks** – The most concerning actors for Industrials are **Mustang Panda**, **Shai‑Hulud**, and **RondoDox** because they target the *software build chain* (signed drivers, npm packages, vulnerable web frameworks) that feed directly into firmware and control‑system updates. --- ## 3. Technical Threat Analysis ### 3.1 Malware Families & Toolsets | Malware / Tool | Primary Vector | Industrial Impact | |----------------|----------------|-------------------| | **ToneShell** (backdoor) | Signed kernel‑mode driver | Persistent foothold on OT gateways, can exfiltrate PLC binaries. | | **MgBot** (IoT bot) | DNS poisoning → malicious payload | Can turn industrial sensors into DDoS bots or data exfiltration points. | | **React2Shell** (RCE) | Unauthenticated web‑app exploit | Enables remote code execution on web‑based HMI/SCADA portals. | | **Shai‑Hulud** (npm supply‑chain) | Malicious npm packages (e.g., *lotusbail*) | Injects credential‑stealing or crypto‑miner code into build pipelines of industrial software. | | **EmEditor download‑page malware** | Compromised website download button | Delivers **Infostealer** to engineers downloading editor for log analysis. | | **MongoBleed (CVE‑2025‑14847)** | Unauthenticated read of uninitialized memory in MongoDB | Exposes configuration files, credentials, and telemetry data from industrial data lakes. | | **IBM API Connect auth‑bypass** (CVE‑2025‑####) | API gateway bypass | Allows attackers to call internal OT APIs without authentication. | | **Fortinet 2FA bypass** (CVE‑2025‑####) | Authentication bypass on firewalls | Direct access to network segmentation devices protecting OT zones. | ### 3.2 Vulnerability Landscape | CVE / Vulnerability | Affected Asset | Exploited By | Relevance to Industrials | |----------------------|----------------|--------------|--------------------------| | **CVE‑2025‑14847 (MongoBleed)** | MongoDB 6.x‑7.x | Ransomware groups, botnets (RondoDox) | Widely used in IIoT telemetry stores; 87 K servers exposed (BleedingComputer, 28 Dec). | | **CVE‑2025‑#### (IBM API Connect auth bypass)** | IBM API Connect 10.x | Unknown APTs (APT‑based credential theft) | API gateways often front OT services. | | **CVE‑2025‑#### (Fortinet 2FA bypass)** | FortiOS 7.x | Criminal botnets | Firewalls sit at OT‑IT boundary; bypass leads to lateral movement. | | **CVE‑2025‑#### (React2Shell)** | Node.js/React web apps | RondoDox botnet | Many HMI/SCADA web front‑ends built on Node/React. | | **Signed driver abuse (WHQL)** | Windows kernel drivers | Mustang Panda, HoneyMyte | Allows stealth persistence on industrial workstations and edge gateways. | | **ColdFusion (CVE‑2025‑####)** | Adobe ColdFusion 2021‑2025 | State‑aligned APTs | Some legacy OT reporting portals still run ColdFusion. | ### 3.3 Attack Surface * **OT‑IT Convergence Points** – Cloud‑based ERP/PLM (e.g., Oracle EBS) now host critical data (Korean Air breach). * **Third‑party SaaS & Development Tools** – npm, EmEditor, IBM API Connect, Fortinet firewalls. * **Industrial Databases** – MongoDB clusters storing sensor data, process logs. * **Edge Gateways & PLCs** – Often run Windows or Linux with outdated drivers, making them vulnerable to signed‑driver rootkits. --- ## 4. Strategic Intelligence ### 4.1 Sub‑Sector Risk Assessment | Sub‑Sector | Top Threats (30 days) | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation Priorities | |------------|-----------------------|------------|--------|----------------------| | **Energy & Utilities** | Ransomware (Oltenia Energy Complex), Utility‑info for sale, MongoBleed data leakage | High | Severe (plant shutdown, safety) | • Harden VPN/remote‑access.
• Patch MongoDB & firewalls.
• Conduct threat‑intel monitoring for utility‑specific data leaks. | | **Automotive & Heavy Equipment** | Ransomware (Chrysler data exfiltration), Supply‑chain NPM attacks | Medium‑High | High (IP loss, production delays) | • Secure build pipelines (SBOM, signed packages).
• Deploy EDR on engineering workstations.
• Conduct regular red‑team exercises on PLM systems. | | **Aerospace & Defense** | ESA breach, Signed‑driver rootkits, Supply‑chain attacks on firmware | Medium | High (national security, export controls) | • Enforce strict code‑signing and hardware‑root‑of‑trust.
• Isolate aerospace design networks (air‑gap). | | **Industrial Manufacturing (MES/SCADA)** | MongoBleed, React2Shell, Mustang Panda kernel rootkits, RondoDox IoT botnet | High | Critical (process disruption, safety) | • Patch MongoDB, upgrade to authenticated access.
• Harden web‑app stacks (WAF, input validation).
• Deploy integrity monitoring on kernel drivers. | | **Transportation (Airlines, Logistics)** | Oracle EBS hack (Korean Air), Undersea cable sabotage, DNS poisoning | Medium | High (flight operations, supply‑chain delays) | • Multi‑factor authentication on ERP.
• Network segmentation for airline ops.
• Monitor DNS traffic for poisoning signs. | ### 4.2 High‑Impact Incidents (selected) | Incident | Date | Impact Summary | Key Lessons | |----------|------|----------------|-------------| | **Oltenia Energy Complex ransomware** | 29 Dec 2025 | Production halted for 48 h; ransom demand €5 M; data exfiltration of SCADA configs. | *Segmentation of OT networks, regular offline backups, and rapid incident response are essential.* | | **Chrysler data breach (Everest ransomware)** | 26 Dec 2025 | >1 TB of design & test data stolen; potential IP leakage to competitors. | *Protect PLM/ERP with DLP, monitor for large‑scale exfiltration, enforce least‑privilege.* | | **MongoBleed (CVE‑2025‑14847) exploitation** | Ongoing (first reported 28 Dec) | 87 K MongoDB servers exposed; many belong to industrial telemetry platforms. | *Enable authentication, network‑level access controls, and patch immediately.* | | **Mustang Panda signed‑driver rootkit** | 30 Dec 2025 | Kernel‑mode persistence on Windows‑based OT gateways; bypassed Secure Boot. | *Enforce driver signing policies, use hardware‑based TPM attestation, monitor for unsigned driver loads.* | | **Utility infrastructure data for sale** | 02 Jan 2026 | Detailed schematics of three US utilities posted on underground forums. | *Treat data leakage as a pre‑attack reconnaissance phase; increase insider‑threat monitoring.* | ### 4.3 Incident‑Response Insights * **Rapid containment** of ransomware in OT requires pre‑approved “air‑gap” rollback procedures and offline configuration snapshots. * **Supply‑chain breach detection**: integrate SBOM verification into CI/CD pipelines; monitor npm registry integrity feeds. * **Rootkit detection**: Deploy kernel‑integrity verification tools (e.g., Microsoft Device Guard, Linux IMA) and continuous driver‑load logging. * **Database exposure**: Use MongoDB’s **audit log** and enable **TLS** for all client connections; enforce IP‑based firewall rules. --- ## 5. Forward‑Looking Assessment ### 5.1 Threat Forecast (next 6‑12 months) | Trend | Expected Evolution | Implications for Industrials | |-------|-------------------|------------------------------| | **Supply‑chain weaponisation of open‑source ecosystems** | More “targeted” malicious npm packages aimed at build tools used by OEMs. | Need for **SBOM‑driven verification** and signed package registries. | | **Kernel‑mode rootkits with legitimate signatures** | APTs will increasingly exploit **WHQL/Code‑Signing** to bypass Secure Boot. | Deploy **runtime integrity monitoring** and enforce **hardware‑based attestation** (TPM, Secure Enclave). | | **Active exploitation of MongoDB & other NoSQL DBs** | Attackers will automate scanning for unauthenticated MongoDB clusters in OT data lakes. | Mandatory **authentication, network segmentation, and encryption‑at‑rest** for all NoSQL deployments. | | **Utility‑specific data‑as‑a‑service markets** | Sale of schematics, SCADA configs will become a commodity for extortion. | Harden **insider‑threat programs**, enforce DLP on engineering documents, and conduct regular **red‑team reconnaissance simulations**. | | **Increased OT‑IT convergence** | More legacy OT devices exposed to cloud services, expanding the attack surface. | Adopt **Zero‑Trust Architecture** for OT, with micro‑segmentation and strict identity‑based access controls. | ### 5.2 Recommended Defensive Priorities | Priority | Actionable Controls | |----------|--------------------| | **1. Patch & Harden Critical Services** | • Deploy emergency patches for **MongoDB (CVE‑2025‑14847)**, **IBM API Connect**, **Fortinet 2FA bypass**.
• Enforce **mutual TLS** and **role‑based access** on all database and API gateways. | | **2. Secure the Software Supply Chain** | • Implement **SBOM** generation and verification for all firmware/firmware updates.
• Use **npm’s “npm audit”** and **Sigstore** for package signing.
• Monitor public NPM feeds for malicious package insertions. | | **3. Detect & Block Kernel‑Mode Persistence** | • Deploy **kernel‑integrity monitoring** (e.g., Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, OSSEC).
• Enforce **code‑signing policies** that only allow drivers signed by the organization’s own CA. | | **4. Strengthen OT Network Segmentation** | • Apply **Zero‑Trust Network Access (ZTNA)** between corporate IT and OT zones.
• Use **industrial firewalls** with deep‑packet inspection for known OT protocols (Modbus, OPC-UA). | | **5. Enhance Threat‑Intel & Monitoring** | • Subscribe to **CVE‑specific KEV feeds** (CISA, NVD) and **industrial‑specific intel feeds** (e.g., Dragos, Nozomi).
• Deploy **DNS‑sinkhole** and monitor for **poisoning anomalies** (Evasive Panda). | | **6. Incident‑Response & Business Continuity** | • Conduct **table‑top exercises** focused on ransomware in OT (as highlighted by The Register, 26 Dec).
• Maintain **offline, immutable backups** of PLC firmware and SCADA configurations. | | **7. Insider‑Threat & Data‑Loss Prevention** | • Apply DLP to engineering repositories (CAD, PLM).
• Monitor for large‑scale exfiltration of design files (e.g., Chrysler, ASUS). | --- ### Closing Note The convergence of **ransomware, state‑sponsored APT tooling, and supply‑chain poisoning** creates a “perfect storm” for the Industrials sector. Immediate, coordinated action on patching, supply‑chain integrity, and OT‑IT segmentation will dramatically reduce the probability of a catastrophic outage or IP loss. Continuous threat‑intel monitoring—especially for emerging **kernel‑mode rootkits** and **MongoDB‑related exploits**—is essential to stay ahead of adversaries that are increasingly targeting the very foundations of industrial digital infrastructure.
